sect1.title: CASE 21
sect1.para: This 18-year-old male presented to the outpatient medical clinic for evaluation of diarrhea and abdominal discomfort. The patient first noted mild abdominal discomfort and three loose bowel movements per day 1 week prior to evaluation. Two days before evaluation, he noted intermittent, crampy periumbilical abdominal pain. He denied drinking well water, fever, blood in the stool, relation of the pain to meals, dysuria, or hematuria.

On examination, the patient was afebrile and had normal vital signs. The abdominal examination was notable for mild lower abdominal tenderness. The fecal examination demonstrated a greenish, watery stool that was negative for occult blood.

Laboratory evaluation included a normal white blood cell count, hematocrit, and platelet count. Examination of the feces microscopically was remarkable for the presence of white blood cells. The organism causing his illness is shown in Fig. 21.1 (Gram stain) and Fig. 21.2 (growth on special medium).

listitem.para: 1. Based on the laboratory findings, what is the likely etiology of this patient’s diarrhea? Is the finding of white cells in the feces consistent with the recovery of this organism? Explain your answer.
2. What special laboratory conditions are necessary to recover this organism?
3. What is the epidemiology of this organism? What simple precautions can be taken to prevent its spread?
4. How have modern means of food production contributed to an increasing incidence of infections with this organism?
5. What is the current status of drug resistance in this organism? What factors are believed to play an important role in this status?

6. Although the patient had evidence of local invasion in the intestinal tract with this organism, bacteremia due to this organism is unusual. Explain this observation. Campylobacter jejuni was locally invasive in this patient, as evidenced by the presence of white blood cells in his feces.
7. What is the most important postinfectious sequela associated with this organism? Briefly describe the pathogenesis of this pathologic process.

sect1.para: 1. Both Vibrio and Campylobacter spp. are slightly curved, Gram-negative rods that cause diarrhea (Fig. 21.1). The pathogenesis of the most important Vibrio species, V. cholerae, is due primarily to the production of an exotoxin, cholera toxin, that causes secretory diarrhea. The stools of patients with severe cases of cholera have a “rice water” appearance. Because of the secretory, noninflammatory nature of the diarrhea, white blood cells are rarely seen in the feces of patients with cholera. Campylobacter spp. cause an invasive diarrhea distinguished by the presence of white blood cells in the stool (1). Up to 50% of patients with Campylobacter diarrhea may have bloody stools due to the presence of red blood cells. The diarrhea seen in this patient is consistent with a Campylobacter infection, and C. jejuni was isolated from his stool (Fig. 21.2). Abdominal pain, as was seen in this patient, is an important although nonspecific feature of the clinical presentation of Campylobacter gastroenteritis. Other causes of invasive diarrhea include Clostridioides difficile, Escherichia coli, Salmonella, and Shigella, and should be considered when a patient presents with gastrointestinal symptoms and dysentery (e. g., blood and/or mucus in the stool).

2. It is important to remember that the facultative aerobic fecal microbiota consists of approximately 107 to 109CFU/g of feces and that finding an enteric pathogen, which may represent only a small fraction of the microbiota, is akin to trying to find a needle in a haystack. Selective media, such as Hektoen and Mac Conkey agars, used to isolate Salmonella and Shigella spp. from feces do not support the growth of Campylobacter spp. (2). To further complicate matters, Campylobacter spp. are microaerophilic organisms (organisms that require lower levels of oxygen than what is present in the atmosphere), so culture conditions that will support their growth must be used. Finally, C. jejuni, the most frequently recovered Campylobacter species, grows optimally at 42°C, the body temperature of chickens, a natural host of this organism. Many laboratories inoculate fecal specimens onto Campylobacter-selective agar and incubate these plates at 42°C under microaerophilic conditions in an attempt to isolate C. jejuni. This approach is problematic since other Campylobacter spp. either fail to grow on certain types of Campylobacter-selective agar or cannot grow at 42°C. Alternative methods are available for the detection of these species.

Nonculture methods have been developed to detect C. jejuni and C. coli, the two species most likely to cause diarrheal infections (3). One assay detects Campylobacter-specific antigens directly in stool specimens by the enzyme immunoassay method. The accuracy of these tests approaches that of culture, and they can be done in <2 hours versus a minimum of 2 days for culture. Alternatively, molecular multiplex tests that detect multiple enteric pathogens, including C. jejuni, C. coli, C. lari, and/or C. upsaliensis, are also being used with increasing frequency, replacing culture and antigen testing. An example multiplex test can detect the nucleic acids of common bacterial (Campylobacter, pathogenic E. coli, Salmonella, Shigella, Vibrio, Plesiomonas shigelloides, Yersinia enterocolitica), parasitic (Giardia, Cryptosporidium, Cyclospora, Entamoeba histolytica), and viral (adenovirus, norovirus, rotavirus, astrovirus, sapovirus) pathogens in ~1 hour.

3. C. jejuni and Salmonella spp. are the two most frequently recovered bacterial causes of gastroenteritis in the United States. Campylobacter is estimated to cause 1.5 million illnesses yearly in the United States (4). C. jejuni, like all enteric pathogens, is spread by the fecal-oral route. A recent meta-analysis assessing campylobacteriosis risk factors demonstrated that international travel was the most important risk factor, followed by undercooked poultry consumption or handling, environmental exposure, and direct contact with farm animals (5). It is important to note that travel-related infections are often associated with consuming contaminated food and exposure to animals and environmental factors, and this relationship is complex. The regions with the highest levels of risk for campylobacteriosis include Southeast Asia, South Asia, Africa, and Latin America.

The risk of infection through consumption or handling of undercooked poultry is associated with high contamination rates. An analysis of Campylobacter contamination on meat between 1994 and 2018 demonstrated that Campylobacter was isolated from 90% of turkey carcasses, 31.5% of market hog carcasses, and 0.2% of ground beef samples (6). In 2018, 1 in 5 chicken carcasses was Campylobacter positive at slaughter, and 1 in 11 chicken breast samples was positive at retail.

Outbreaks of Campylobacter infection are not commonly reported in the United States but are increasing in frequency. For example, the CDC reports that the average number of outbreaks reported between 2004 and 2009 was 22, 31 outbreaks were reported between 2010 and 2012, and 29 from 2013 through 2017 (7). In recent years, outbreaks not associated with meat have been reported. In 2014, an outbreak of 99 cases of Campylobacter infection was reported in Utah that were associated with the consumption of raw milk (8). Between 2016 and 2019, more than 160 people from across the United States were infected with multidrug-resistant Campylobacter after being exposed to pet store puppies. Exposure to cattle and swine feces increases the risk of acquiring Campylobacter, but the exposure is not always obvious. For example, 22 participants became infected with Campylobacter after being exposed to surface water contaminated with cattle and swine feces during a high-intensity mud race (9). These mud races are often hosted by the U. S. military and located in rural areas where muddy obstacle courses can be constructed.

Contaminated water is an infrequent vehicle for this infection. There is no evidence of person-to-person spread of this organism. Adequate cooking of poultry and avoidance of cross-contamination of other foods will prevent most Campylobacter cases. The infectious dose for this organism appears to be intermediate between those for Shigella spp. (low) and Salmonella spp. (high). Like Salmonella and Shigella spp., Campylobacter is an organism that causes disease mainly during the warm-weather months, with a peak incidence in July. One of the interesting observations concerning this organism is that the highest incidence of infection is in infants (<1 year old) and adolescents and young adults (15 to 29 years old). It is the most frequent cause of bacterial gastroenteritis in college students in the United States, with isolation rates on certain campuses as high as 15% in individuals with diarrhea. In the adolescent and young adult age group, infections are more common in males. It is speculated that these individuals are preparing the bulk of their meals for the first time in their lives and may not practice the best food preparation hygiene.

To prevent Campylobacter infection, the CDC recommends washing hands thoroughly before and after food preparation, keeping raw poultry away from other foods and using separate cutting boards for raw meat, cooking food thoroughly before consuming, not consuming raw milk, not drinking untreated water, and practicing healthy habits with pets (10).

4. Animals and animal products are the primary source of infection for Campylobacter (11). “Factory farming,” in which large numbers of animals are grown in close quarters, results in high colonization rates with this organism. For example, cattle “finished” on feedlots have a much higher colonization rate than grazing animals. Essentially all chickens raised in commercial chicken barns, which can hold as many as 100,000 animals, are colonized with Campylobacterby the fourth week of life. Studies have shown that contamination of poultry carcasses can increase significantly during automated processing. Agricultural research is focusing on ways to reduce or prevent contamination during processing. For example, research from 2021 performed by the U. S. Department of Agriculture used CDC FoodNet surveillance data to assess the roles of food, season, temperature, and geographic location in Campylobacter infection (12). The findings from this study suggest that foods other than poultry may play a greater role in campylobacteriosis than previously thought and that regional differences in sporadic Campylobacter infection persist even after controlling for season, temperature, and food purchasing patterns.

5. Two classes of antimicrobials are used to treat Campylobacter infections: macrolides and fluoroquinolones. Resistance to the fluoroquinolone ciprofloxacin has been increasing over the years, and in the United States, a 2023 study estimates demonstrated resistance rates just above 29% (13). In some countries, the use of a fluoroquinolone is no longer an effective treatment option (14). Currently, the rate of macrolide resistance in the United States remains low. Resistance to ciprofloxacin is much more common than resistance to macrolides. The reasons for this difference are multifactorial.

First, a single mutation in the DNA gyrase, the target protein for the fluoroquinolones, can result in high-level resistance. In contrast, macrolide resistance usually requires multiple mutations to reach clinical significance, rendering macrolide resistance much less common in animals (<10%) and even less so in humans. Second, fluoroquinolone-resistant mutants appear more “fit” than macrolide-resistant ones. This is significant because in the early part of this century, “animal use only” fluoroquinolones such as enrofloxacin were widely used to prevent bacterial respiratory infections in large chicken houses that contained as many as 30,000 birds. The use of fluoroquinolones in these birds resulted in the selection of mutant strains of Campylobacter that were not only resistant to the “animal use only” fluoroquinolones but also had cross-resistance to the human ones. The overcrowded chicken houses also resulted in the colonization of large percentages of animals with these resistant organisms. Although enrofloxacin has been banned for use in poultry in the United States, the fluoroquinolone-resistant organisms have persisted due to superior fitness. Additionally, high rates of fluoroquinolone resistance have been noted in Campylobacter isolates from feedlot cattle in the United States, with resistance rates reaching 35.4% in C. jejuni and 74.4% in C. coli (15). Due to the mutable nature of Campylobacter, the use of fluoroquinolones in cattle production, and the acquisition of Campylobacter infection in humans from food animal consumption, scientists emphasize the importance of preventing the development and dissemination of fluoroquinolone-resistant Campylobacter infections.

Ciprofloxacin is frequently prescribed for travelers to low- and middle-income countries, to be taken if they develop diarrhea. This is done because ciprofloxacin is active against many bacterial pathogens they may encounter. Unfortunately, ciprofloxacin resistance is increasing not only in Campylobacter but also in Salmonella and Shigella, calling into question the durability of this approach.

To respond to the threat of antibiotic-resistant Campylobacter, the CDC continues to track changes in antibiotic resistance seen in clinical isolates and to enhance surveillance through advanced technological approaches like whole-genome sequencing of isolates obtained from people, meat, and food animals. Many new and non-antibiotic approaches to controlling Campylobacter have been proposed and are undergoing research and include prebiotics, probiotics, fatty acids, bacteriocin, bacteriophages, immunization, and antibiotic adjuvants.

6. Like Shigella spp., this organism rarely causes bacteremia in the immunocompetent host (1). The most likely reason is that this organism, unlike Salmonella spp., does not survive within phagocytic cells. It is either locally ingested and killed by phagocytes in the intestinal wall or carried by lymphatic drainage to the Peyer’s patches, where it is killed. Occasional cases of C. jejuni bacteremia occur, but most are transient because the reticuloendothelial system can eliminate this organism from the bloodstream.

Campylobacter-associated diarrhea and bacteremia are much more common in individuals living with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) who have CD4 counts of <200/μl. However, with the widespread use of combined antiretroviral therapy in high-income countries, Campylobacter bacteremia has declined dramatically in this patient population. In addition to individuals living with HIV, those at higher risk of more severe disease include patients with hypo- or agammaglobulinemia or those who have defects in humoral immunity. In these patients, gastrointestinal illness is frequently accompanied by bacteremia. While bacteremia caused by Campylobacter is rare, it is an important condition for the medical microbiologist to be aware of. Due to their small size and Gram-negative staining reaction, Campylobacter organisms may be difficult to visualize on a positive blood culture Gram stain. Blood cultures that repeatedly flag positive with no organism seen in the Gram stain should always be investigated further, for example, with the fluorescent acridine orange stain, to visualize structures that were missed on the Gram stain (Fig. 21.3). If curved rods are seen on a follow-up stain and the patient has a history of gastrointestinal illness, Campylobacter should be considered.
C. fetus rather than C. jejuni is the species of Campylobacter most likely to cause bacteremia.

sect1.para: 7. Guillain-Barré syndrome is characterized by acute flaccid paralysis in which patients become either hyporeflexic or areflexic (1). Patients require intubation in ~25% of cases, and secondary pneumonia is an important contributor to its 5% mortality rate. Guillain-Barré syndrome can have multiple antecedents that typically occur 3 to 6 weeks prior to the onset of symptoms. It is estimated that 30% of these episodes are associated with C. jejuni diarrhea and that it occurs after 1 in 1,000 to 1 in 2,000 C. jejuni infections.

The disease is thought to be a result of molecular mimicry, in which antibodies targeted against the lipooligosaccharide of C. jejuni cross-react with peripheral nerve ganglioside, resulting in an acute inflammatory polyneuropathy. Two treatment strategies have been developed. One uses plasma exchange to remove antibodies and complement, which mediates this inflammatory neuropathy. The other uses immunoglobulin to bind the autoantibodies produced in response to the Campylobacter infection or inhibit the activation of complement by autoantibody.

Other autoimmune syndromes associated with Campylobacter are reactive arthritis (Reiter syndrome), the major manifestation being inflammation of either the urethra or conjunctiva, and hemolytic-uremic syndrome. Campylobacter may also be responsible for flares of inflammatory bowel disease. This organism, as well as other diarrheal pathogens, has also been associated with irritable bowel syndrome. As we unravel the role of the intestinal microbiota in inflammatory and irritable bowel disease, we are likely to develop a better understanding of the role of these bacteria in these disease processes.

listitem.para: Campylobacter is a common cause of invasive diarrhea distinguished by the presence of white blood cells in the stool.

Culturing Campylobacter poses several challenges and requires the use of selective media to inhibit the growth of other gastrointestinal organisms, microaerophilic growth conditions, and incubation at 42°C.

Multiple nonculture methods have been developed for detecting C. jejuni and other Campylobacter species and include enzyme immunoassay and molecular multiplex tests, which can detect common bacterial, parasitic, and viral pathogens as quickly as 1 hour.
Campylobacter is spread by the fecal-oral route and is estimated to cause 1.5 million illnesses yearly in the United States.

International travel is the most important risk factor for Campylobacter infection, followed by undercooked poultry consumption or handling, environmental exposure, and direct contact with farm animals.

Outbreaks of Campylobacter infection are not commonly reported in the United States but are increasing in frequency. Recently, these have included exposures not related to meat, including consumption of raw milk, contact with pet store puppies, and mud races.
Campylobacter is the most frequent cause of bacterial gastroenteritis in college students in the United States, with isolation rates on certain campuses as high as 15% in individuals with diarrhea.

To prevent Campylobacter infection, the CDC recommends washing hands thoroughly before and after food preparation, keeping raw poultry away from other foods and using separate cutting boards for raw meat, cooking food thoroughly before consuming, not consuming raw milk, not drinking untreated water, and practicing healthy habits with pets.

Fluoroquinolones and macrolides are the two antibiotic choices for the treatment of Campylobacter infection. Fluoroquinolone resistance has increased significantly over the years, while macrolide resistance has remained low.

It is rare for immunocompetent people to develop severe disease from Campylobacter, and the infection is often self-limited. In individuals living with HIV and those with other underlying immune deficits, gastroenteritis may be accompanied by more severe disease, such as bacteremia.

Several postinfectious sequelae may occur with Campylobacter. The most severe, Guillain-Barré syndrome, is a condition characterized by acute flaccid paralysis in which patients become either hyporeflexic or areflexic. It is estimated that 30% of these episodes are associated with C. jejuni diarrhea and that it occurs after 1 in 1,000 to 1 in 2,000 C. jejuni infections. Other autoimmune syndromes associated with Campylobacter include reactive arthritis (Reiter syndrome), inflammation of either the urethra or conjunctiva, hemolytic-uremic syndrome, and flares of inflammatory bowel disease.
